subtitles.dialogue_text: Tokuma Shoten, Nippon Television, Hakuhodo present
Based on "Omoide Poroporo" by Hotaru OKAMOTO and Yuko TONE
Theme song performed by Harumi MIYAKO
Screenplay written & directed by Isao TAKAHATA
With ten days off, I figured you'd go abroad.
But you're off to Yamagata, right?
As soon as I get home, we're traveling to Grandma's.
So I won't get yelled at for ages.
Lucky you! Are you going away too?
Yeah, to Nagano. How about you, Taeko?
My Dad bought a summer place.
Such a bad grade in math again.
But I got a "B" in science.
Are we going away for the holidays?
I'll take you to a movie. Find out what's playing.
Not that. I mean to the country...
We don't have relatives in the country, so don't ask.
My family had lived in Tokyo for generations.
I envied friends who had family in the countryside.
It's too late to book. All hotels will be full.
But I really want to go...
We're regulars. They'd have a room for us.
Good idea. Taeko's never been there.
Is it in the mountains... by the sea?
You get to ride the bullet train.
And others, like the Swan Bath and the Violet Bath.
Since father's working, you four go.
I'm amazed you show up every morning.
No-one will be around for ages.
I leave today. Any message for your husband's family?
Not really. Just buy them something.
Say it's from us and I'll pay you back.
Don't worry about it. How's Mom?
She was mad you turned down that guy's proposal.
"At 27, that's the best offer she's going to get!"
She's got a point. You're not young anymore...
You've got to settle down eventually.
By the way, did you really work in the fields last year?
Yes, harvesting rice. This year, I'm picking safflower.
Thanks to you, I finally have family in the countryside.
So, I'm making the most of it!
Rather than stay in that old house,
why not treat yourself to a fancy hotel for once?
Maybe you'd meet a nice boy.
No way. You mean a hotel like "Onoya"?
You've got to get over it.
Let go of that baggage from the past!
My sisters, of course, would never go to a place like atami.
Bored to tears, I went alone to the Brothers Grimm Bath
the Mermaid Bath, the Lemon Bath,
and the Violet Bath, one after the other.
When I got to the Roman Bath, my head was spinning.
And with that, my trip was over.
Followed by endless weeks of vacation.
The other day, my sisters and I were reminiscing.
as the memories came flooding back.
I'm the one who asked for it.
Didn't you ask in the store?
Strange fruit they have in those hot countries.
I know how to eat the pineapple!
Wouldn't a carving knife be best?
Live long enough and you see lots of different things.
- You can have mine. - Mine too.
Bananas are still the king of fruits.
The year I fainted at the baths and had my first pineapple...
the Beatles came to Japan, started the rock 'n'roll band
My sister Nanako, a freshman in art school, was up on all the trends.
When she wore a mini-skirt, she'd cover her bottom going up the stairs.
My clever sister, Yaeko, was crazy about some Takarazuka actress.
My sisters' memories are mainly of fashion and pop trends.
For them, 1966 is the height of nostalgia.
Whereas I was only ten years old.
My favorite band had yet to debut....
My only memories are the back and forth between school and home.
And it might be entered in an essay contest.
- I'd be so happy... - You didn't finish lunch again.
Why do you hide the pickles inside the bread?
I've got to throw it away. What a waste.
I'd rather you were a good eater than a good essay writer.
How can you drink that stuff?
Milk's okay. It's onions I hate.
I'm leaving carrots so I've got no choice.
Who decided we can only leave one thing?
You'll eat my onions next time?
People who run in the corridor...
...when the hall monitor says stop, should be punished.
How are you gonna do that?
If I bumped into you I'd bounce a mile!
- Let's change the rule. - But we already decided.
Raise your hand if you want to speak.
The hall monitor should chase the offender,
Then the hall monitor should be punished for running too.
The hall monitor shouldn't be punished because...
...it's like a policeman chasing a speeding car.
So, the hall monitor can chase offenders.
I just read an article on the Vietnam War.
There are many unfortunate people overseas.
Lucky to have you near me!
We should be grateful for our food.
We're allowed to leave one thing on our plates,
- It can't hurt to leave one thing. - Let's all leave milk...
- Give it to someone else... - Of course.
- People hide leftovers in bread. - That's cheating!
If you want to speak, raise your hand!
That night in bed, after chatting to my sisters
Our pet dog... . School sports day...
being scared by gross horror comics....
So many little details, one after the other...
playing in my head like a movie,
Is there a Miss Okajima here?
Hirota in our class says he likes you.
Shuji Hirota and Taeko Oka jima
Taeko, you sure you don't know him?
No... of course not... not at all.
Don't write silly things on the wall.
Taeko told us to tell you.
You said you liked Okajima in Room 5.
So, we wrote it for you.
We just went to see Hirota.
We told him not to write things on walls.
Only Tono can hit his pitches.
Our team plays his in the next game.
Don't you dare cheer their side!
But even I could tell he was superb.
Between the cold and the excitement, I ran to the bathroom five times.
If Tono couldn't hit him, how could we?
You missed the throw and three runs scored.
Coach said he'd buy us ice cream.
Hirota, you should go see her.
Rainy day or cloudy or sunny day.
I didn't intend the ten year-old me to come on this trip.
But somehow, once she showed up
But why me in the 5th grade?
Second hour, all boys play baseball, all girls to the gym.
Today I'm going to talk about something very important.
You'll leave grade school, then junior school then high school.
Then become grown ups and have babies.
A woman's body prepares to have babies.
Mom told me when I was in fourth grade,
She said tall girls or big girls get their periods early.
- Are you gonna buy them? - I am.
Nurse said we all need them eventually.
The girls are buying underpants in the infirmary.
Why is the school selling underpants?
It's supposed to be our secret.
I said to keep it secret.
Now they'll be looking up our skirts.
Looking up skirts was all the rage and periods became an obsession.
The nurse said it's very important.
I started when I was in fourth grade.
That's why I skip P. E. Sometimes.
You skip P. E. With a period?
He even said he felt sorry for us.
You told him about skipping P. E.?
He promised not to tell the others.
all girls who skip P. E. Have periods!
Please excuse Taeko from P. E. Because of her cold.
No. You don't have a fever.
Don't blame me if it gets worse.
Since when was she so fond of P. E.?
I'm missing P. E. Too. Just like you.
I wish I could play, too.
I'm not. I have a cold.
Don't touch it, don't touch it!
That was close. Almost caught it...
What a silly thing to say.
Mom said it's nothing to be ashamed of.
Like it or not, a butterfly must first...
live as a caterpillar before it can fly away.
Maybe I remember those days because
I was going through the caterpillar stage.
Something definitely changed when I started working.
at work and at play we girls were livelier and more spirited than guys.
It was like we'd finally found our wings.
maybe we were just flexing them pointlessly.
Perhaps the fifth grade me was tagging along
with a message for me to reflect
Anyway, I decided to sleep the rest of the way.
Excuse me, has the Tokyo train gone?
Excuse me, but who are you?
I'm Toshio. Kazuo s second cousin.
I thought you were trying to steal my bag.
That's terrible. Didn't I ask your name?
Yes, you did. I just thought... sorry...
He asked me last night to come pick you up
I should've used my Dad's car
You know a lot about it?
I like it because I'm a farmer.
Remember last year's party at the farmhouse?
A bunch of guys turned up, right?
They came to check out the girl from Tokyo.
I heard you're picking safflower. Do you dye fabric?
Safflower's kind of unusual. Well, maybe not for you.
It's known as a famous local product but
- Wasn't it big in the old days? - For the merchants, sure.
They got rich, but for farmers, it was just another crop.
Do you know: In time whose skin will it grace, this crimson flower.
The famous Basho poem? I read it before coming.
I only learned it last night.
I also read that the flower-pickers
couldn't afford to wear the rouge they made.
Is that where you had the barbeque?
There'll be another this year, too.
Are market reforms making agriculture difficult?
As things go, Japanese farming might just collapse,
anything worth struggling for will be hard work.
Isn't it the same in the city?
But fewer people live for their work.
I don't live for my job but I don't hate it either.
I could farm twenty-four hours a day.
It's fascinating to raise living things.
Not that. We've got some animals,
but I'm talking about rice, apples, cherries. They're all living things.
If we take good care of them,
I feel like they'll do their best for us.
Not at all. I get what you mean.
To tell the truth, I used to work in an office.
That's why I'm so enthusiastic. It's very important.
I quit work and joined my friend's organic farm.
People said I'm nuts, but I don't regret it.
We use all natural stuff, no pesticides or anything.
I've seen the labels: "No chemicals used"
We bring out the plant's life force.
It's cool... like lending nature a hand.
Sounds easy, but it's damn hard work.
I was told to take you straight to the fields.
Don't you pick the flowers early while the thorns are still soft?
I'm trying to become an early-riser.
That's why I took the night train.
Great to have you back, Taeko.
We made your bed just in case.
That's okay. Look, I'm raring to go!
Young people here don't wear them any more.
You look like the real thing Taeko.
And so began my second taste of country life.
How could this yellow flower produce such a bright red?
They told me a sad tale from the old days.
and their bare hands would get pricked by the thorns.
It was their blood that made the red so deep.
they must've felt toward the fancy city girls.
To make a handful of rouge took nearly 500 lbs of petals.
This rouge was literally worth its weight in gold.
The petals are washed, trodden, then exposed to the air and the sun.
As the petals oxidize, they gradually turn red.
fermentation turns them bright red and they become sticky.
Pounded, wrung into balls and sun-dried, they finally become
The liquid from the pressing wasn't wasted either.
The red pigment in the yellow broth
Cheer me up with your pretty color.
For those village girls, with no chance of make-up or kimonos,
Safflower dye brought color into their drab lives.
The yellow pigment dissolves in water leaving clothes a light pink.
Machines now take away some of the work,
but the petal's still need picking every day.
Rouge cakes soon mould, and the flowers wait for no one.
No sooner are you done picking, than they bloom again.
When the rains come, work continues into the early hours.
Pleasantly tired, I thought about the flower-pickers of old.
If I could've worked like this as a child,
my school essays would've been really interesting.
5,000 yen? I can't give you that.
You said you'd buy me new sneakers.
I'm not sure. There must be cheaper ones.
How about the ones you've got?
No. You never do your chores.
Did you ask for a dress for your Barbie Doll?
Didn't you promise to ask only at Christmas and your birthday?
All of a sudden, the ten year-old me was back.
Yaeko got a kimono and it wasn't even her graduation.
You keep asking for lots of little stuff,
we get one or two big things.
Anyway, that kimono will be yours in the end.
- Some people don't get anything. - Exactly.
Then give me that enamel purse.
Didn't you give it to her yet?
You're too old for that. Give it to her.
Then I won't give it to you.
I'm not buying you a new one.
Good. I actually really like it.
Ready for dinner. Take this away.
See, has to be thrown away.
Don't throw it away! Please Mother.
Father, buy me an enamel purse.
You said you didn't want it.
You said it, you have to do it.
You said it was just the three of us.
Because I finished my homework. Is that a problem?
It's Chinese food. The more the merrier.
If you don't want to come, stay here.
We didn't go out, of course.
My face was swollen and a cold towel
wondering why it was always me.
Was it the first time he hit you?
Yes, the first and only time.
Dad slaps me often... well, sometimes.
When it's only once, you can't stop thinking why.
It's hard to imagine you a selfish brat.
I wasn't just fussy about onions, either.
Now I don't feel like I'm that bad.
Your poor Mom. I shouldn't encourage you.
I'm giving up on the Pumas.
Maybe I'll slip you some pocket money.
Let's go for a drive to Zao.
You went to Yamadera last year, right?
The family said it was okay.
The views at Zao were beautiful.
But Zao had become famous and touristy.
How come you re not married?
Most of my friends are single.
In elementary school, could you do fractions?
When they said reverse the numerator and denominator, could you do it?
I wasn't bad at math though.
I bet you don't remember 'cause it was easy.
It seems that people who could do it
went on to have easy lives.
One girl, completely average ...not even good at math,
always could do it perfect right away.
I was no good at it.
Not smart enough to know when to quit.
And... um... we did blow pictures.
Yes. We drop paint on the paper...
You blow like this, really hard, right?
So, I got a headache. From blowing so hard.
That's why you did so badly?
Do you know the answers now?
Have Yaeko help you with them.
Nanako's not back yet. Can I wait til after dinner?
Please teach her. She doesn't seem to get it.
Is she alright in the head?
Taeko, your sister's going to help.
You had a headache from blowing, didn't you?
Say your times table from the top.
I know that. I'm in fif th grade already!
Just flip the top and the bottom and multiply.
Then why do you get it wrong?
Yaeko, one step at a time.
What's dividing a fraction by a fraction anyway?
Two-thirds of an apple divided by a quarter means...
So, it's one, two, three, four, five, six...
No, no, no, no. That's multiplication.
How come it's less when you multiply?
Two-thirds of an apple divided by a quarter...
just remember to inverse and multiply.
If she got half right, it'd be worth scolding her.
Should you get her IQ checked?
They said it was fine when she started.
Remember she fell downstairs as a baby?
Nonsense. She's just no good at math.
She chats too much in class.
If she'd just listen,; even an idiot can do it.
It's only two more years until Junior High.
divided by a quarter... I can't even picture it.
Even now, dividing fractions is difficult.
We farmers give up too easily.
We just yield to the flow and follow what they do in the cities.
Let's rethink the real meaning of prosperity.
Return to the old ways of farming.
So, that explains the organic farming?
It's great the way you hold onto your memories of math class.
It wasn't meant to impress you.
People say you work in a great place
but I could never give myself up to it completely.
I really admire your devotion to farming.
There aren't many people like you.
So we can't just carry on as normal.
We've got to think about the future.
We help each other out, cheer one another along,
otherwise we can't keep it up.
I've been with friends a few times.
Come next winter. I'll teach you.
No, but I'm an instructor there.
An instructor? You must be great.
All my friends are too. It's nothing.
At last, we're in the middle of nowhere.
Sorry. I didn't mean it like that.
City people see the trees and rivers
But what you see here is all made by man.
Every bit has its history, not just the fields and rice paddies,
someone's Great-Great Grandpa planted it, or cleared it,
gathered firewood or picked mushrooms there.
Mankind battles nature and receives from it.
They evolve together, and create this scenery.
So without man, this wouldn't exist?
So they've always taken great care
to give her a helping hand in return.
A collaboration between man and nature...
That's the heart of country life.
That's why I feel so at home.
I didn't grow up here, but somehow always felt...
my soul was at home here.
What's so great about organic farming?
Only the theory. Like I said...
giving nature a hand is hard work.
Things haven't changed in a hundred years.
There's not enough labor to weed by hand.
Toshio let me try a variety of things...
...until I felt I knew all about country life.
"Behold, the crows fly home. First one..."
At last I can say this in the right setting.
It was my line in a school play.
I only ever had small roles too.
Only lead roles, since there are so few of us.
These days people leave and go to the cities.
And now there are fewer kids.
I see. But getting the big roles must be fun.
Not really. I prefer sports. I'm a pretty fast runner.
Good for you. I was always mediocre.
The sports version of "Village Child A"
Still, I'll never forget that line as long as I live.
It was going to make me a star.
Even though you weren't the lead?
Because I was the most enthusiastic.
I rehearsed endlessly in front of the mirror.
The line was so short, I felt something missing.
"Behold, the crows fly home. First one..."
I know. You made up more!
Look up there, the crows fly home.
Farewell dear crows. You take care now.
But let's stick to the script.
It wasn't a good line, so I didn't mind.
I realized that I could act even when there were no lines.
It was worth the effort. "Village Child A" was a hit.
People asked if I'd had lessons. Teachers praised me...
...and then the dynamite blew up right in my face!
We need a girl to star in our college play.
As a service to the community,
Of course we'd bring her straight home.
I'll be in a real play.
Not with a bunch of kids but with real grown-ups!
Oh, oh, oh, oh what a wonderful day
A nice boy from the university wants you in their drama.
You were so good in the school play.
At least you're good at something.
She's certainly better at that than she is at math.
I was lead in "The Poor Sparrow" but no one came for me.
Are you going to do it?
This could lead to a career.
Start rehearsing now, it's perfect timing.
Show business people are no good.
Why did you have to mention a career?
Or show business? You know Dad...
Why did you say that Nanako?
Poor boy, poor boy, Don't you feel sorry for me?
We won't take much of her time.
Sorry you came so far for nothing.
.... Such a long way from home...
Aoki's going to play the part instead.
Today her Mom met her at school
to get her changed into a fancy dress.
A frilly thing out to here...
Don't tell anyone you got the first offer.
Because that would hurt Aoki very much.
Where is it heading, Hyokkori Pumpkin Island? Where will it take us?
There 'll be hard times, there 'll be sad times,
We hate to cry, so let's laugh instead
I joined the drama group in high school.
I couldn't forget what had happened.
It was a lot of fun, acting and all...
but it wasn't for me. As for becoming a star...
I guess Dads are the same all over.
When I was in high school, I so wanted to live in Tokyo.
I even wrote to my cousin about schools there.
I gave up. But it annoyed me
to hear other guys bragging about life in Tokyo.
Not anymore though. I respect my dad...
But I know how you felt.
No it's the same, I understand.
But we'll never lose heart, we hate to cry, so let's laugh instead.
I also watched Hyokkori Pumpkin Island.
Machine Gun Dandy was so cool.
Those songs were full of encouragement.
"If today's no good, you'll have tomorrow"
"If tomorrow's no good, you'll have the next day"
"If that's no good, there'll be another"
That song, about putting things off, Toshio took
I liked his approach to life.
Thank you for having me for so long.
Very much. I feel so at home.
I've lived here all my life.
Been to Tokyo just once. For your sister's wedding.
You think it's better than Tokyo?
Tokyo's packed with cars, buildings... People shouldn't live like that.
You really like it here then?
Yes. The nice surroundings, the kind people...
Why don't you live here? With Toshio?
Since his brother moved to Tokyo,
why don't you stay here and marry Toshio?
Don't pay any attention. She's joking.
Don't deny you wouldn't like it.
It's not a matter of what we'd like...
she works so hard on the land, it's a joy to watch.
There'd be nothing better than her marrying Toshio.
You're being rude. You're embarrasing her.
She's got a decent job in Tokyo. Besides, she's older than him.
There are jobs in Yamagata too.
Most of the young wives work these days, so...
She's only been here twice on holiday.
Suddenly bringing this up... you're upsetting her.
I didn't say that. I said let's be realistic.
We don't even know how Toshio feels.
One look at him and it's obvious.
Don't dismiss it before we've asked her.
See what you did. You can't rush these things.
I don't think I was wrong.
I'd never even thought of being a farmer's wife.
even imagining it might be possible.
"I'd love to... ." like in a movie.
Suddenly my love of the country, and my play-farming,
Declaring my love for country life
based on a ten day vacation, now felt so embarrassing.
I ain't shaking hands with you.
When it's his turn to feed the ducks, he takes the bread home.
Glad he's not sitting next to me.
He should sit with the boys.
Don't you dare tell anyone what we said.
What are you doing out here?
You're getting wet. Quick, get in.
I knew a boy named Abe.
He came from another school. He sat next to me.
His family was poor. He never had sports gear.
Always picking his nose or wiping it on his sleeve...
And if I complained or even dared frown at him,
I hated it. I longed for the end of the term,
I hated holding hands in dance class,
hated having to lend him my homework.
The girls gossiped and called him names.
I thought it was terrible to talk behind his back.
He was transferred in the middle of the term.
The teacher made us all shake hands and say goodbye.
A feeling of disgust swept the room.
Walking around, shaking hands with us,
Back at his own desk, only I was left.
When I held out my hand he said,
That's why he didn't shake my hand.
I just pretend to be nice.
You're strange, today. Not the usual you.
I don't know what happened, but...
It's nothing to do with that.
I just feel bad about what happened.
I think that boy was stupid.
Maybe he didn't shake your hand because he liked you.
No, he liked the class president.
He was always acting tough with me.
Hands in pockets, spitting, swearing, swaggering along,
I know how he feels. When I was little,
I used to bully the girl I liked.
He shook hands with everyone but me.
Girls never understand how boys feel.
He couldn't bully any boys. He had no friends.
You sat next to him, an easy target.
He needed you to be tough with.
No way he wanted to shake hands with everyone.
He could only prove how tough he was with you.
I felt so guilty and so sorry for him
Sometimes at night you see raccoons here.
They must be worried about me.
This'll be the talk of the town.
I'm sorry. You've been so kind.
I wonder what happened at the house, though?
Please, for my sake, don't ask anyone.
I began to think of my feelings for him,
and of his feelings for me, for the very first time.
How come he seemed to sort out my mixed-up thoughts?
How come I let him get so close?
Somehow he seemed older than me.
He was the one I wanted to shake hands with.
My mind raced as I sat beside him.
We'll see you in the winter.
Sorry. Next time I'll be fine,
I'll leave the ten year-old me, at home.
Some say love, it is a river
Some say love, it is a razor
that leaves your soul to bleed.
Some say love, it is a hunger,
I say love, it is a flower,
It's the heart, afraid of breaking,
It's the dream, afraid of waking,
It's the one who won't be taken.
And the soul, afraid of dyin',
When the night has been too Ionely
and the road has been too long,
And you think that love is only
for the lucky and the strong,
Lies the seed, that with the sun's love,
in the Spring becomes the Rose.
English translation by Kennedy TAYLOR, Aya FUTAMI,
English subtitles by AURA and Nippon Cine Arts
